definition: a pre-Tang Dynasty genre of poetry, relatively free in form, usually having four, five, six or seven characters per line
abbr. for Shijing 詩經|诗经[Shi1 jing1], the Book of Songs
a genre of poetry, developed in the Tang Dynasty, characterized by its strict form
regular verse/strict poetic form with eight lines of 5, 6 or 7 syllables and even lines rhyming
old verse/poetry in the old style
Ma Zhiyuan (c. 1250-1321), Yuan dynasty dramatist in the 雜劇|杂剧[za2 ju4] tradition of musical comedy, one of the Four Great Yuan Dramatists 元曲四大家[Yuan2 qu3 Si4 Da4 jia1]
to mark a text with dots and circles/to punctuate
study of classic texts, including interpretation, glossaries and commentaries
form of writing novels that comprise lots of poetry in the body of the text, popular in the Ming Dynasty
names of the tunes to which 詞|词[ci2] poems are composed
